messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 54 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: A Many-Objective Problem Where Crossover is Provably Indispensable

Paper Abstract: Abstract This paper addresses theory in evolutionary multiobjective optimisation (EMO) and focuses on the role of crossover operators in many-objective optimisation. The advantages of using crossover are hardly understood and rigorous runtime analyses with crossover are lagging far behind its use in practice, specifically in the case of more than two objectives. We present a many-objective problem class together with a theoretical runtime analysis of the widely used NSGA-III to demonstrate that crossover can yield an exponential speedup on the runtime. In particular, this algorithm can find the Pareto set in expected polynomial time when using crossover while without crossover it requires exponential time to even find a single Pareto-optimal point. To our knowledge, this is the first rigorous runtime analysis in many-objective optimisation demonstrating an exponential performance gap when using crossover for more than two objectives.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 54 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 54"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Black-box complexity of parallel search with distributed populations",
        "An nsga-iii algorithm for solving multi-objective economic/environmental dispatch problem",
        "Better running time of the non-dominated sorting genetic algorithm II (NSGA-II) by using stochastic tournament selection",
        "Investigating the normalization procedure of NSGA-III",
        "Comparison of nsga-iii with nsga-ii for multi objective optimization of adiabatic styrene reactor",
        "Approximating a multi-dimensional pareto front for a land use management problem: A modified moea with an epigenetic silencing metaphor",
        "Evolutionary Algorithms for Solving Multi-Objective Problems",
        "Applications of Multi-Objective Evolutionary Algorithms",
        "Standard steady state genetic algorithms can hillclimb faster than mutation-only evolutionary algorithms",
        "Design and analysis of diversity-based parent selection schemes for speeding up evolutionary multi-objective optimisation",
        "Escaping local optima using crossover with emergent diversity",
        "Analysing the robustness of nsga-ii under noise",
        "A proof that using crossover can guarantee exponential speed-ups in evolutionary multi-objective optimisation",
        "Crossover can guarantee exponential speed-ups in evolutionary multi-objective optimisation",
        "Normal-boundary intersection: A new method for generating the pareto surface in nonlinear multicriteria optimization problems",
        "Multi-Objective Optimization using Evolutionary Algorithms",
        "An evolutionary many-objective optimization algorithm using reference-point-based nondominated sorting approach, part i: Solving problems with box constraints",
        "A fast and elitist multiobjective genetic algorithm: NSGA-II",
        "Analyzing randomized search heuristics via stochastic domination",
        "Optimal static and self-adjusting parameter choices for the (1+(ŒªŒª\\lambda,ŒªŒªŒªambda)) genetic algorithm",
        "A first runtime analysis of the NSGA-II on a multimodal problem",
        "Runtime analysis for the NSGA-II: provable speed-ups from crossover",
        "Crossover can provably be useful in evolutionary computation",
        "More effective crossover operators for the all-pairs shortest path problem",
        "From black-box complexity to designing new genetic algorithms",
        "The (1 + (ŒªŒª\\lambda, ŒªŒªŒªambda)) global SEMO algorithm",
        "Introducing elitist black-box models: When does elitist behavior weaken the performance of evolutionary algorithms?",
        "An improved nsga-iii algorithm based on distance dominance relation for many-objective optimization",
        "A multi-objective genetic local search algorithm and its application to flowshop scheduling",
        "On the analysis of evolutionary algorithms‚Äîa proof that crossover really can help",
        "Real royal road functions‚Äîwhere crossover provably is essential",
        "Substitute distance assignments in nsga-ii for handling many-objective optimization problems",
        "How crossover helps in pseudo-boolean optimization",
        "Running time analysis of multiobjective evolutionary algorithms on pseudo-boolean functions",
        "Empirical comparison between moeas and local search on multi-objective combinatorial optimisation problems",
        "Artificial intelligence in multi-objective drug design",
        "Runtime analyses of nsga-iii on many-objective problems",
        "A tight o‚Äã(4‚Äãk/pc)ùëú4ùëòsubscriptùëùùëêo(4k/p_{c}) runtime bound for a (Œº+1)ùúá1(\\mu+1) ga on JumpksubscriptJumpùëò\\textsc{Jump}_{k} for realistic crossover probabilities",
        "An analysis on recombination in multi-objective evolutionary optimization",
        "Subset selection by pareto optimization with recombination",
        "A comprehensive review of machine learning in multi-objective optimization",
        "A parametric study of crossover operators in multi-objective evolutionary algorithm",
        "A comprehensive review on multi-objective optimization techniques: Past, present and future",
        "How crossover speeds up building-block assembly in genetic algorithms",
        "Evolving populations of solved subgraphs with crossover and constraint repair",
        "Fixed-parameter tractability of crossover: Steady-state gas on the closest string problem",
        "A dql-nsga-iii algorithm for solving the flexible job shop dynamic scheduling problem",
        "Methods for the analysis of evolutionary algorithms on pseudo-Boolean functions",
        "A mathematical runtime analysis of the non-dominated sorting genetic algorithm III (NSGA-III)",
        "Multiobjective optimization for crash safety design of vehicles using stepwise regression model",
        "Behavior of crossover operators in nsga-iii for large-scale optimization problems",
        "Runtime analysis for the nsga-ii: Proving, quantifying, and explaining the inefficiency for many objectives",
        "Runtime analysis of the sms-emoa for many-objective optimization",
        "A first mathematical runtime analysis of the non-dominated sorting genetic algorithm II (NSGA-II)"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 54 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in A Many-Objective Problem Where Crossover is Provably Indispensable, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
